document.docTitle: Metabolites isolated from the human intestinal fungus Penicillium oxalicum SL2 and their agonistic effects on PXR and FXR

paragraph.docTitle:
Metabolites isolated from the human intestinal fungus
Penicillium oxalicum
SL2 and their agonistic effects on PXR and FXR

document.paragraph:
Wen-Yu Zhao a, 1
, Zhi-Lin Luan
a, 1
, Cheng-Peng Sun

paragraph.emphasis:
Dalian Key Laboratory of Metabolic Target Characterization and Traditional Chinese Medicine Intervention, College of Pharmacy, College of Integrative Medicine, The National
&
Local Joint Engineering Research Center for Drug Development of Neurodegenerative Disease, Dalian Medical University, Dalian, 116044, People’ s Republic of China
Jiangsu Key Laboratory of New Drug Research and Clinical Pharmacy, Xuzhou Medical University, Xuzhou, 221004, People’ s Republic of China

subSection.paragraph:
Penicillium oxalicum SL
2 Trichocomaceae Metabolites
FXR
PXR
ABSTRACT

Intestinal commensal fungi are vital to human health, and their metabolites play a key role in the reciprocal relationship. In the present work, eighteen alkaloids and seven monoterpenoids were isolated from the fermentation of the human intestinal fungus
Penicillium oxalicum SL
2, including seven undescribed alkaloids (penicilloxalines A-G), three undescribed monoterpenoids (penicilloxalines H-J), and fifteen reported compounds. The structures of the isolated compounds were identified by HRESIMS, 1D and 2D NMR, electronic circular dichroism spectra and quantum chemical calculations. Some metabolites displayed moderate agonistic effects against the pregnane X receptor (PXR), whereas (6 R )3,7-dimethyl-6,7-dihydroxy-2( Z )-octenoic acid displayed a significant agonistic effect against the farnesoid X receptor (FXR) with an EC 50 value of 0.43 μ M, which was verified by investigating FXR downstream target genes and proteins, such as small heterodimer partner 1 (SHP1), fibroblast growth factor (FGF), and bile salt export pump (BSEP).

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. Dalian Key Laboratory of Metabolic Target Characterization and Traditional Chinese Medicine Intervention, College of Pharmacy, College of Integrative Medicine, The National & Local Joint Engineering Research Center for Drug Development of Neurodegenerative Disease, Dalian Medical University, Dalian, 116044, People’ s Republic of China . E-mail addresses: wach_edu@sina.com (C. Wang), maxc1978@163.com (X.-C. Ma). 1 These authors contributed equally to this work.

caption.paragraph: Table 1 1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz) data of compound 1 in DMSO‑ d 6

subSection.paragraph:
Herein, the metabolites investigation of
Penicillium oxalicum Currie, J.N.
; Thom, C. ( Trichocomaceae ) strain SL2, produced twenty-five compounds, including ten undescribed penicilloxalines A-J and fifteen known penicilloxalines ( Fig. 1 ). Their structures were determined by 1D and 2D NMR, HRESIMS, and electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra as well as time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) ECD calculations. All the isolated compounds were assayed for their agonistic effects toward pregnane X receptor (PXR) and farnesoid X receptor (FXR). Molecular dynamics (MD) was used to further study the underlying interaction of compound 18 with FXR.

Penicilloxaline A ( 1 ) was isolated as an amorphous powder, and its molecular formula was determined to be C 27 H 39 N 3 O 3 based on its HRESIMS ion at m/z 452.2926 [M H] (calcd. for C 27 H 38 N 3 O 3 , 452.2919) and 13 C NMR data. The 1 H NMR data of 1 ( Table 1 ) revealed the presence of a tri-substituted benzene ring at δ H values of 7.34 (1H, d, J = 7.6 Hz, H-4), 6.98 (1H, d, J = 7.6 Hz, H-6), and 6.91 (1H, t, J = 7.6 Hz, H-5), one N -methyl group at δ H 2.46 (1H, s, CH 3 -18), and three methyl groups at δ H 1.15 (1H, s, CH 3 -28), 0.90 (1H, s, CH 3 -23), and 0.77 (1H, s, CH 3 -22). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed 27 carbon signals, including one amide carbonyl carbon at a δ C 181.0, six aromatic carbons at δ C 142.5, 130.2, 129.7, 123.8, 121.3, and 120.7, two oxygenated carbons at δ C 75.7 and 73.2, three nitrogenated carbons at δ C 63.3, 54.8, and 49.7, one N -methyl caron at δ C 28.7, and three methyl carbons at δ C 24.5, 23.2, and 22.8. Comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data from 1 with penioxalamine A isolated from
P. oxalicum TW
01-1 ( Hua et al., 2014 ) indicated differences at C-18, C-25, and C-26. The chemical shift values of C-25 and C-26 were deshielded from δ C values of 60.1 and 55.6 in penioxalamine A to δ C 75.7 and 73.2 in 1 ( Hua et al., 2014 ), and the C-18 chemical shift value was shielded from δ C 174.7 in penioxalamine A to δ C 28.7 in 1 ( Hua et al., 2014 ). The HMBC correlations of CH 3 -28 with C-25/C-26 and the shift values of C-25 ( δ C 75.7) and C-26 ( δ C 73.2) suggested the locations of two hydroxyl groups at C-25 and C-26 ( Fig. 2 ). The HMBC correlation of CH 3 -18 with C-11 revealed that the N -methyl group was linked at C- 11 in a combination of the proton signal of the N -methyl group ( δ H 2.46, s). In the NOESY spectrum of 1 , cross-peaks of CH 3 -28 with CH 3 -22/H-25, H-20 with CH 3 -22/H-13, and CH 3 -23 with H-4/ CH 3 -18 suggested α -orientations of CH 3 -18, OH-25, and OH-26, β -orientations of H-13, H-20, and CH 3 -28 ( Fig. 3 ), and a ( R *)-configuration of C-3. To determine the absolute configuration of 1 , quantum chemical calculations were applied based on DFT. The calculated ECD spectrum of (3 R ,11 R ,13 S ,20 S ,25 S ,26 S )- 1 at the CAM-B3LYP/def-tzvp level agreed with its experimental ECD spectrum ( Fig. 4A ), demonstrating the (3 R ,11 R ,13 S ,20 S ,25 S ,26 S )-configuration of 1 . Accordingly, the structure of 1 is shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as penicilloxaline A.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Structures of compounds 1–25 isolated from
P. oxalicum SL
2.

subSection.paragraph:
The molecular formula of penicilloxaline B ( 2 ) was determined to be C 13 H 14 N 2 O 6 according to its HRESIMS data at m/z 293.0779 [M H] (calcd. for C 13 H 13 N 2 O 6 , 293.0779) and 13 C NMR data. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 2 ) for 2 displayed the presence of two substituted benzene rings at δ H 7.86 (1H, dd, J = 7.9, 1.5 Hz), 7.68 (1H, dd, J = 8.5, 1.5 Hz), 7.53 (1H, td, J = 8.5, 1.5 Hz), and 6.92 (1H, dd, J = 7.9, 1.5 Hz), and a methoxy group at δ H 3.60 (1H, s). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) for 2 showed 13 carbon resonances, including three carbonyl carbons at δ C 173.0, 168.4, and 163.4, six aromatic carbons at δ C 145.9, 134.2, 131.2, 119.6, 113.2, and 112.2, an olefinic carbon at δ C 131.4, and a methoxy group at δ C 51.2. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 2 were similar to those of penipacid C ( 19 ) isolated from
P. paneum
SD-44 ( Li et al., 2013 ), with the exception that 2 had three carbons ( δ C 173.0, 51.2, and 30.3) more than 19 and the chemical shift value of C-12 was deshielded from δ C 11.4 in 19 to δ C 29.1 in 2 ( Li et al., 2013 ), indicating their differences mainly at the side chain of C-12. This deduction was further confirmed through an HMBC experiment showing correlations of H 2 -12 with C-11/C-14, H-13 with C-9, and OCH 3 -14 with C-14 ( Fig. 2 ). Therefore, the structure of 2 was defined as shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as penicilloxaline B.

Penicilloxaline C ( 3 ) had the molecular formula C 13 H 14 N 2 O 6 based on its HRESIMS ( m/z 293.0781 [M H], calcd. for C 13 H 13 N 2 O 6 , 293.0779) and 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ). The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 3 closely resembled those of 2 , except for the downfield shift of C-11 from δ C 163.4 in 2 to δ C 161.9 in 3 , the upfield shift of C-14 from δ C 173.0 in 2 to δ C 173.9 in 3 , and the signals of the methoxy group [ δ C 51.2 and δ H 3.60 (s) in 2 ; δ C 51.9 and δ H 3.82 (s) in 3 ], suggesting their differences at C-11 and C-14. The HMBC correlations of OCH 3 -11 with C-11 confirmed their differences. Thus, the structure of 3 was determined to be penicilloxaline C.

Analysis of HRESIMS data of penicilloxaline D ( 4 ) revealed that 4 possessed a molecular formula of C 14 H 16 N 2 O
6 in
conjunction with its 13 C NMR data. The signals of the two methoxy groups were δ C 51.9 and 52.0 and δ H 3.59 (s) and 3.76 (s) in the 1 H NMR spectrum of 4 , and 4 had a mass that was 14 Da greater than 3 , revealing that 4 was a methylated derivative of 3 . In the HMBC spectrum of 4 , cross-peaks of OCH 3 -14 with C-14 and OCH 3 -11 with C-11 confirmed the linkages of two methoxy moieties. The structure of 4 is shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as D.

Penicilloxaline E ( 5 ) was obtained as an amorphous powder, and its molecular formula was determined to be C 17 H 14 N 2 O 4 based on the HRESIMS data ( m/z 309.0886 [M H], calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 4 , 309.0881). The 1 H NMR data of 5 displayed the presence of a quinazolinone moiety at δ H 8.10 (1H, s), 8.09 (1H, br d, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.80 (1H, br t, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.60 (1H, br d, J = 7.5 Hz), and 7.52 (1H, br t, J = 7.5 Hz) in combination with the characteristic 13 C NMR data ( δ C 159.9, 147.4 × 2, 134.5, 127.1, 126.9, 126.1, and 121.2) ( Table 3 ). Four aromatic protons were present at δ H 6.90 (2H, d, J = 8.2 Hz) and δ H 6.54 (2H, d, J = 8.2 Hz) in the 1 H NMR spectrum of 5 , and signals of nine representative carbons were present at δ C 170.5, 155.9, 129.7 × 2, 126.9, 115.2 × 2, 59.9, and 33.9 in its 13 C NMR spectrum, which suggested the presence of a tyrosine moiety. The presence of the two abovementioned moieties was further confirmed by the 2D NMR data of 5 . The HMBC correlations of H-12 with C-1/C-9 determined the linkage of a quinazolinone and tyrosine moiety through a nitrogen atom ( Fig. 3 ). The calculated ECD spectrum of (12 S )- 5 agreed well with its experimental ECD spectrum, requiring its absolute configuration ( Fig. 4B ). Accordingly, the structure of 5 is shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as penicilloxaline E ( 5 ).

Penicilloxaline F ( 6 ) had a molecular formula of C 17 H 14 N 2 O 5 according to the [M H] peak at m/z 325.0819 (calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 5 , 325.0824) and 13 C NMR data. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 6 closely resembled those of 5 , and their difference was at the right aromatic ring ( Table 3 ). The chemical shift value of C-16 was deshielded from δ C 115.2 in 5 to δ C 145.1 in 6 , and the chemical shift values of C-15, C-17, and C-19 were shielded from δ C 129.8, 156.1, and 129.8 in 5 to δ C 116.1, 143.8, and 119.4 in 6 . The HMBC correlation of H-18 with C-16 suggested the hydrolyzation of C-16. The absolute configuration of 6 was assigned as 12 S through a comparison of its calculated and experimental ECD spectra ( Fig. 4C ). Thus, the structure of 6 was defined in Fig. 1 and referred to as penicilloxaline F ( 6 ).

The molecular formula of penicilloxaline G ( 7 ) was determined to be C 18 H 16 N 2 O 4 based on the HRESIMS and 13 C NMR data. Comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 7 and 5 revealed the presence of a methoxy group [ δ C 52.6; δ H 3.69, s] in 7 and the upfield shift of C-11 from δ C 170.5 in 5 to δ C 169.3 in 7 . The HMBC cross-peaks of OCH 3 -11 with C-11 suggested that 7 was a methylation derivative of 5 . Its absolute configuration was determined to be 12 S based on the result of the quantum chemical calculation ( Fig. 4D ). Therefore, the structure of 7 is shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as penicilloxaline G.

HRESIMS and 13 C NMR data analysis of penicilloxaline H ( 8 ) indicated that its molecular formula was C 14 H 24 O 6 . Comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 8 and ( Z , R )-3,7-dimethyl-oct-2- ene-1,6,7-triol revealed the presence of a succinic acid moiety [ δ C 173.7, 172.1, 28.9, and 28.8] and the downfield shift of C-1 from δ C 57.5 in ( Z , R )-3,7- dimethyl-oct-2-ene-1,6,7-triol to δ C 60.6 in 8 ( Wang et al., 2018 ), which suggests that 8 was a succinylation derivative of the known compound. This deduction was confirmed by the HMBC experiment ( Fig. 2 ). The configuration of the Δ 2(3) olefinic moiety was determined as the ( Z )-configuration based on NOESY cross-peaks of H-2 with CH 3 -9 and H 2 -1 with H-4a ( Fig. 3 ). The optical rotation of 8 was similar to that of ( Z , R )-3,7-dimethyl-oct-2-ene-1,6,7-triol ( Wang et al., 2018 ), requiring a (6 R )-configuration.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Selected HMBC and 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of compounds 1 , 2 , 5 , and 8 .
Fig. 3. Selected NOESY correlations of compounds 1 and 8 .
Fig. 4. Experimental and calculated ECD spectra of 1 (A) and 5–7 (B–D) at the CAM-B3LYP/def-tzvp level.

subSection.paragraph: Penicilloxaline I ( 9 ) was assigned a molecular formula of C 10 H 18 O 5 based on its HRESIMS ion at m/z 217.1074 ([M H] calcd. for C 10 H 17 O 5 , 217.1076) and 13 C NMR data ( Table 4 ). The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 9 closely resembled those of (6 S )-3,7-dimethyl-6,7-dihydroxy-2 ( Z )-octenoic acid ( 15 ) ( Wang et al., 2018 ). The downfield shift of C-8 from δ C 24.7 in (6 S )-3,7-dimethyl-6,7-dihydroxy-2( Z )-octenoic acid ( 15 ) to δ C 66.2 ( 9 ) suggested the location of a hydroxy group at C-8 ( Wang et al., 2018 ), which was further confirmed through an HMBC experiment showing correlations of CH 3 -10 with C-8. The configuration of the Δ 2(3) olefinic moiety in 9 was the same as that of 8 described by the NOESY correlations of CH 3 -9 with H-2. Thus, the structure of penicilloxaline I ( 9 ) was identified as shown in Fig. 1 .

The molecular formula of penicilloxaline J ( 10 ) was defined as C 10 H 16 O 4 by HRESIMS and 13 C NMR data. A detailed comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 10 and (6 S )-3,7-dimethyl-6,7-dihydroxy-2( Z )- octenoic acid ( 15 ) demonstrated that 10 was a 6-oxo derivative of 15 because of the downfield shift of C-6 from δ C 72.7 in 15 to δ C 215.0 in 10 ( Wang et al., 2018 ). In the HMBC spectrum of 10 , correlations of CH 3 -8/ CH 3 -10 with C-6 confirmed the deduction. The configuration of the Δ 2(3) olefinic moiety in 10 was identical to that of 8 and 9 according to similar 13 C NMR data and the biosynthetic background. Therefore, the structure of penicilloxaline J ( 10 ) was determined as shown in Fig. 1 .

caption.paragraph: Table 2 1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz) data of compounds 2 4 in DMSO‑ d – 6
Table 4 1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz) data of compounds 8 10 in DMSO‑ d – 6

paragraph.emphasis: 2.2. Agonistic effects of isolated metabolites against PXR and FXR

caption.paragraph:
Table 3 1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz) data of compounds
5 – 7
in DMSO‑ d 6

subSection.paragraph: These isolated compounds were assayed for their agonistic effects against PXR and FXR. Compounds 5 , 11 , 19 , and 22 exhibited significant agonistic effects against PXR with EC 50 values of 7.73, 4.04, 0.12, and 0.21 μ M, respectively, whereas compound 18 displayed a significant agonistic effect against FXR with an EC 50 value of 0.43 μ M ( Table 5 ).

To confirm the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR, the mRNA and protein expression levels of FXR and its downstream targets, such as SHP1, BSEP, and FGF, were investigated after 24 h incubation of compound 18 (2 μ M) with HepG2 cells. As shown in Fig. 5A–C , administration of compound 18 (2 μ M) resulted in the upregulation of the mRNA levels of FXR, SHP1, and BSEP, and expression levels of FXR, SHP1, FGF, and BSEP were increased after the administration of compound 18 (2 μ M). FXR is a nuclear transcription factor, and its nuclear translocation leads to the binding of its downstream target genes; therefore, we investigated the transcriptional regulation of FXR modulated by compound 18 . As described in Fig. 6 , the translocation of FXR from the cytoplasm to the nucleus was observed after treatment with compound 18 . These results indicate that compound 18 activated FXR and transcriptionally regulated the expression levels of its downstream targets.

To investigate the potential interaction of compound 18 with FXR, GROMACS software was used to perform a 50-ns MD stimulation. As shown in Fig. 7A–C , the RMSD of compound 18 with FXR remained under 2 Å, the RMSF of residues ranged from 0.5 Å to 3.5 Å, and the pocket volume of FXR remained at approximately 1000 Å
3 in
the presence of compound 18 during a 50-ns MD stimulation, which suggests that this MD stimulation was reliable. Compound 18 could form a stable complex with FXR with an energy of approximately 5.8 × 10 5 kJ/mol during a 50-ns MD stimulation ( Fig. 7D ). The total binding energy was 78.383 kJ/mol, indicating that compound 18 had a good binding effect with FXR. The energy contribution results indicated that the van der Waals interaction energy (177.442 kJ/mol) was strong, the electrostatic (35.666 kJ/mol) and SASA nonpolar solvent (13.918 kJ/mol) interaction energy was weak, and polar solvation (88.643 kJ/mol) hindered the binding of compound 18 and FXR ( Fig. 7E ). During the 50- ns MD stimulation, Compound 18 could form 1–4 hydrogen bonds with four amino acid residues, Val325, Met328, Phe329, Ser332, and Tyr369 ( Fig. 7F ). The distances of compound 18 with amino acid residues Val325, Met328, Phe329, and Tyr369 were monitored by GROMACS. As shown in Fig. 7G, a complex of compound 18 with FXR achieved equilibrium during the 50-ns MD stimulation, whereas Ser332 maintained a distance under 3.0 Å with OH-6 and OH-7 of compound 18 ( Fig. 7H ) after the 50-ns MD stimulation. During the 50-ns MD stimulation ( Fig. 8A ), compound 18 only interacted with Ser332 by way of two hydrogen bonds, indicating the potential role of Ser 332 in the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR.

caption.paragraph:
Agonistic effects of compounds
1 – 25
against PXR and FXR.

Fig. 5. (A) Effects of compound 18 (2 μM) towards FXR, SHP1, and BSEP mRNA levels. (B) Effects of compound 18 (2 μM) towards FXR, SHP1, FGF, and BSEP expression levels. (C) Quantitative analysis of FXR, SHP1, FGF, and BSEP expression levels. Data were shown as the mean ± SD, n = 3 (*p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001 compared to the Ctrl group). CDCA (80 μM) was used as the positive control.
Fig. 6. The nuclear translocation effect of compound 18 (2 μM) against FXR.

Fig. 7. The RMSD (A) and RMSF (B) of compound 18 with FXR in 50 ns MD stimulation. (C) The volume of pock for a complex of compound 18 and FXR in 50 ns MD stimulation. (D–F) The energy of the complex (D), energy of contribution (E), and hydrogen bond number (F) of compound 18 with FXR in the 50 ns MD stimulation. (G) The distance of compound 18 with amino acid residues Val325, Met328, and Phe329. (H) The distance of compound 18 with amino acid residues Ser332 and Tyr369.

subSection.paragraph: Analysis of the 3D crystal structure of FXR (PDB code: 3BEJ) revealed that this protein (Q96RI1-2, NM_005123) is one of five FXR isoforms (Q96RI1-1, Q96RI1-2, Q96RI1-3, Q96RI1-4, and Q96RI1-5) based on the UniProt database (https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/Q96RI1), while the FXR plasmid used in this study was cloned from Q96RI1-4 (NM_001206992). A comparison of the amino acid sequences of Q96RI1-2 and Q96RI1-4 suggests that the former possesses ten fewer amino acids than the latter, as previously described ( Luan et al., 2019 , 2021 ). On the basis of this analysis, a site-directed amino acid mutation was carried out. The S342V mutation abolished the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR ( Fig. 8B ), which further reveals the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR through the hydrogen bond interaction with amino acid residue Ser332.

Herein, the investigation of the fermentation of the human intestinal fungus
P. oxalicum SL
2 led to the isolation and identification of twenty-five
compounds (1 – 25), including
seven previously undescribed alkaloid penicilloxalines A ¡ G (
1 – 7
), three previously undescribed monoterpenoid penicilloxalines H-J (
8 – 10
), and fifteen reported compounds (
11 – 25
). Compounds 5 , 11 , 19 , and 22 displayed significant agonist effects against PXR with EC 50 values from 0.12 ¡7.73 μ M, whereas compound 18 gave a significant agonist effect against FXR (EC 50 = 0.43 μ M). MD stimulation revealed hydrogen bonds between the Ser332 amino acid residue of FXR and the 6-OH and 7-OH of compound 18 . Site-directed amino acid mutation confirmed the vital role of Ser 332 in the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR. Therefore, the hydroxyl groups of compound 18 were revealed as the active functional groups of compound 18 .

caption.paragraph: Fig. 8. (A) The 3D structure and hydrogen bond interaction of compound 18 with FXR at the 50th ns MD stimulation. (B) The agonistic activity of compound 18 against the wild-type, mutant R341V, or S342V FXR. Data were shown as the mean ± SD, n = 4 (*p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001 compared to the Ctrl group; # p < 0.05, ## p < 0.01, ### p < 0.001 compared to the WT group).

subSection.paragraph: An Autopol IV automatic polarimeter was used to measure the optical rotation. 1D and 2D NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV-600 NMR spectrometer (Bruker, Karlsruhe, Germany ), chemical shift values are expressed in δ (ppm) using the peak signals of the solvent DMSO‑ d 6 ( δ H 2.50 and δ C 39.5) as references, and coupling constants ( J in Hz) are given in parentheses. ECD spectra were measured on a JASCO CD-MDS 450 spectrophotometer.

The human intestinal fungus in this work was isolated from human feces and was identified as
Penicillium oxalicum Currie, J.N.
; Thom, C. ( Trichocomaceae ) strain SL2 by Dr. Qiulong Yan using the 18S rDNA sequence. A sample of this fungal strain (ID: P7015) was deposited in the College of Pharmacy, Dalian Medical University.

The strain
P. oxalicum SL
2 was inoculated into 200 × 1 L Erlenmeyer flasks that contained 140 g rice and 187 mL distilled water and had previously been sterilized by autoclaving at 121 ◦ C for 30 min and then incubated at 28 ◦ C for 30 days. The solid rice media was extracted with EtOAc (80 L) 3 times. After removing the solvent, the residue ( 247 g ) was obtained.

The EtOAc extracts ( 247 g ) were isolated through a silica gel column and eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:1 to 1:1) to afford four fractions: E1 E4. Separation of Fraction E2 ( 48 g ) through silica gel column chromatography afforded four subfractions: E21 E24. Subfraction E21 ( 10 g ) was purified by an ODS column (10%–90% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (50%–80% MeOH) to afford compounds 4 ( 3.7 mg ) and 22 ( 3.7 mg ). Compounds 8 ( 2.8 mg ), 10 ( 5.2 mg ), 15 ( 17.3 mg ), 16 ( 17.1 mg ), and 17 ( 9.1 mg ) were separated from Subfraction E22 ( 8 g ) through ODS column chromatography (10%–90% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (28%–55% MeOH). Subfraction E23 ( 10 g ) was separated by an ODS column and eluted with MeOH–H 2 O (from 1:9 to 9:1) to afford nine subfractions, E231 E239, and compound 2 ( 48 mg ). Subfraction E232 ( 800 mg ) was purified by preparative HPLC (28%–55% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (10%–25% CH 3 CN), yielding compounds 7 ( 6.8 mg ), 12 ( 10.5 mg ), 18 ( 13.1 mg ), and 19 ( 8.6 mg ). Purification of Subfraction E234 ( 712 mg ) through preparative HPLC (35% CH 3 CN) resulted in the production of compounds 3 ( 5.1 mg ) and 23 ( 2.3 mg ). Subfraction E24 ( 10 g ) was subjected to an ODS column and eluted with MeOH–H 2 O (from 1:9 to 7:3) to obtain eight subfractions: E241 E248. Subfraction E242 ( 350 mg ) was isolated by preparative HPLC (10% CH 3 CN) to afford compounds 9 ( 3.9 mg ) and 25 ( 35.8 mg ). Separation of Subfraction E243 ( 821 mg ) through ODS column chromatography (28%–55% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (15%–20% CH 3 CN) afforded compounds 5 ( 7.3 mg ), 14 (4.0 mg), 20 ( 8.4 mg ), and 21 ( 3.5 mg ). Subfraction E246 ( 120 mg ) was purified by preparative HPLC (40% CH 3 CN) to afford compound 24 (2.0 mg).
Finally, Fraction E3 ( 20 g ) was purified by an ODS column (10%– 100% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (30%–50% MeOH), yielding compounds 1 (23.0 mg), 6 ( 3.1 mg ), 11 (10.0 mg), and 13 (9.0 mg).

White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D + 43 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 218 (3.8), 260 (3.4) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 232 (7.12), 268 (+4.03); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 452.2926 [M H] (calcd. for C 27 H 38 N 3 O 3 , 452.2919).

White amorphous powder; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (3.9), 357 (3.7) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 293.0779 [M H] (calcd. for C 13 H 13 N 2 O 6 , 293.0779).

White amorphous powder; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 222 (3.7), 351 (3.8) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 293.0781 [M H] (calcd. for C 13 H 13 N 2 O 6 , 293.0779).

White amorphous powder; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 222 (3.9), 344 (3.8) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 307.0936 [M H] (calcd. for C 14 H 15 N 2 O 6 , 307.0936).

White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 39 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 227 (3.7), 268 (3.4), 303 (3.2) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 275 (6.11); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 309.0886 [M H] (calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 4 , 309.0881).

White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 87 ( c 0.3, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 228 (3.9), 277 (3.3) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 213 (5.92), 228 (5.91), 286 (1.82); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 325.0819 [M H] (calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 5 , 325.0824).

White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 62 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 228 (3.9), 268 (3.4), 303 (3.2) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 236 (7.82), 272 (4.95); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 323.1026 [M H] (calcd. for C 18 H 15 N 2 O 4 , 323.1032).

White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D +61 ( c 0.2, CHCl 3 ); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 202 (3.9) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 4 ; HRESIMS m/z 287.1503 [M H] (calcd. for C 14 H 23 O 6 , 287.1500).

White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 15 ( c 0.2, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (3.8) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 4 ; HRESIMS m/z 217.1074 [M H] (calcd. for C 10 H 17 O 5 , 217.1076).

White solid; [ α ]20D 35 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (3.9) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 4 ; HRESIMS m/z 201.1127 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 10 H 17 O 4 , 201.1121).

The agonistic effects of compounds against FXR were measured as previously described, using chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA, 80 μM) as the positive control ( Luan et al., 2019 , 2021 ). Human hepatoma HepG2 cells were transiently transfected with human FXR cDNA (Q96RI1–2, NM_005123) and luciferase pGL3.0 vector with the FXRE reporter (basic bile salt export pump BSEP) with the pcDNA3.1 vector expression plasmid, and the null-Renilla luciferase plasmid was used as an internal control. HepG2 cells were treated with vehicle DMSO (0.1%) or compounds after 24 h of transfection. HepG2 cells were harvested after 24 h incubation, and luciferase activity was measured using the Dual-- Luciferase® Reporter Assay System (Promega, USA ). All experiments were repeated three times, and the EC 50 value was analyzed by GraphPad Prism software.

According to the manufacturer’ s instructions, RNA was extracted from the HepG2 and HK 2 cells after treatment with the compounds for 24 h. Reverse transcription was conducted using a reverse transcription kit ( Beijing , China ). The cDNA was used as a template for RT-qPCR. All primers were designed by Oligo 6.0 software (MBI Inc., Colorado , USA ).

Cell samples were lysed in RIPA lysis buffer supplemented with protease and phosphatase inhibitors. The protein concentration was quantified using a BCA Protein Assay Kit (Beyotime Institute of Biotechnology, Hangzhou, China ). The same amount of denatured protein was loaded on denaturing SDS polyacrylamide gels and transferred to polyvinylidene fluoride membranes, which were blocked in 5% skim milk. Membranes were incubated with specific primary antibodies overnight at 4 ◦ C. After washing, the blots were incubated with secondary antibodies for 2 h at room temperature. Blots were revealed with a chemiluminescence (ECL) western blotting system. ImageJ software (Rawak Software Inc., Germany ) was used to quantitate the protein expression level.

HepG2 c ells were treated with compounds and fixed with 4% PFA after 24 h. Cells were washed with ice-cold PBS three times, treated with 0.3% Triton X-100 for 10 min, and blocked with 0.5% BSA for 30 min. Cells were incubated with primary FXR antibody overnight at 4 ◦ C. Before incubation with the fluorescent secondary antibody for 1 h at room temperature, the cells were washed three times. DAPI was used to stain the nuclei, and the cells were then analyzed under a confocal microscope.

The crystal structure of protein FXR (PDB ID 3BEJ) was downloaded from the Protein Data Bank, and the active pocket of FXR was defined according to its ligand. The 3D structure of compound 18 was optimized at the CHARMm force field, and then the potential interaction of compound 18 with FXR was analyzed by the CDOCKER tool in Discovery Studio 2016 ( Luan et al., 2019 , 2021 ). The GROMACS package was used to investigate the MD simulation using the AMBER99SB force field ( Luan et al., 2021 ; Sun et al., 2020a , 2020b ; Yun et al., 2020 ; Zhao et al., 2021 ). The best pose of compound 18 with FXR was subjected to the steepest descent energy minimization to relax the system. All the parameters were set as default in this calculation. The GROMACS package was used to analyze the root mean square deviation (RSMD), root mean square fluctuations (RMSF), and other parameters, and the results were plotted by GraphPad Prism and PyMOL software.
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

The authors thank the National Natural Science Foundation of China (81872970), Dalian Science and Technology Leading Talents Project (2019RD15, 2020RJ09), Distinguished professor of Liaoning Province (No. XLYC2002008), Liaoning Provincial Key R &D Program (No. 2019JH2/10300022), Natural Science Foundation of Liaoning Province (No. 2020-MS-256), Dalian Outstanding Youth Science and Technology Talent (No. 2015J12JH201), and Dalian Young Star of Science and Technology (No. 2019RQ123).
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112974.
